questions.stem:
A 22-year-old man presents with symptoms that have progressed over 3 months. The patient has history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. Physical examination shows scattered crackles on lung auscultation and mild tachycardia. Vital signs: Temp 38.3°C (101°F), BP 112/70 mmHg, HR 104/min, RR 18/min. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis and elevated C-reactive protein. Recent literature on mitral, surgical, right has highlighted clinically important patterns that can be tested at the bedside. Which of the following pathways is most directly involved?

Additional history reveals intermittent constitutional symptoms and a partial response to symptomatic therapy. A targeted diagnostic workup is performed to distinguish between competing etiologies based on physiology, pathology, and pharmacology principles.
questions.explanation_short: Use core pathophysiology to map symptoms and labs to a single best explanation; avoid distractors that do not fit the mechanism.

choices.text: Right-to-left shunt from intracardiac defect
choices.explanation: This is a plausible distractor, but it does not fully explain the key discriminating clues or would be expected to produce a different set of findings.

choices.text: Diffusion impairment due to interstitial fibrosis
choices.explanation: This option best matches the pattern described in the vignette. It provides a unifying mechanism that explains the key clinical features and labs.

questions.stem:
A 63-year-old man presents with symptoms that have progressed over 6 months. The patient has recent course of broad-spectrum antibiotics. Physical examination shows jaundice and right upper quadrant tenderness. Vital signs: Temp 38.3°C (101°F), BP 112/70 mmHg, HR 104/min, RR 18/min. Laboratory studies show elevated creatinine and proteinuria. Recent literature on metabolic, acidosis, amyloidosis has highlighted clinically important patterns that can be tested at the bedside.
